intro.description: This cheat sheet provides some guidelines how the Memory Analyzer tool could be used to find memory problems.

item.title: Analysis steps overview
item.description:
1. Get a quick overview of the heap
2. Search for single objects with big retained size - it is easy to analyze them afterwards
3. Search for groups of objects with big retained size - if there are no huge single objects, try to form different groups with as few as possible objects inside

item.title: 1. Get a quick overview
item.description: As a starting point of the analysis get a quick overview.

subitem.label: Look at the class histogram and find the classes with biggest shallow heap size.
Switch to classloader view and find the classloaders with biggest shallow heap size.
Execute the "top_consumers" query in the "Leak Identification" submenu to get a summary of the top-level dominators

item.title: 2. Search for and explore the biggest objects
item.description: Open the dominator tree and look at the biggest objects. If there are some objects with too big retained size, do the following:

subitem.label: Select one of the suspicious objects in the Dominator Tree and expand it's subtree. Repeat this until you have reached a significant drop in the retained sizes between the parent and the child nodes. This is the point where the memory accumulation has happened.
Right click to open the context menu. Select "Open in Paths to GC roots..." and any of the sub options
Now you can see the real reference path with all the field names. From here on fine analysis could be done.

item.title: 3. No huge single objects? Try to find suspicious object groups
item.description:
If the dominator tree does not contain any objects which have a very big retained size, then try to find groups of objects which occupy a lot of memory.
Usually smaller groups are easier to further analyze.

item.title: 3.1. Grouping objects
item.description: Here are several ideas of how to find interesting object groups

subitem.label: Open the dominator tree and group the objects by class. The sum of the retained sizes of the objects at the top-level of the dominator tree is equal to the total heap size. Therefore, there's a big chance to find an interesting group here.
Go to the Histogram view, and find the dominators of the biggest class(es) - use the "Immediate dominators" context menu, filter out the java* package.
Switch to classloaders view and calculate the retained size for the top ones - use the "Calculate Retained Size" context menu

If there is an array class in the Histogram which occupies too much memory, then try to find groups of arrays with one and the same size. Execute "Java Collections-->Arrays Grouped By Size" context menu query.

item.title: 3.2. Analyzing object groups
item.description: Once you have found a suspicious group of objects, you can use one of the following for further analysis

subitem.label: Calculate the retained size of the group
Display and analyze what objects are in the retained set of the group

Calculate the shortest path to each of the objects in the group, look at the paths together, and check if there is a common part (is possible via histogram's context menu "open in multiple paths from GC root)
